required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Decreasing ED Utilization by Nudging Patients to Call Their Providers
clinical_study.official_title: Decreasing ED Utilization by Nudging Patients to Call Their Provider or Triage Nurse After Women's Health Procedures

brief_summary.textblock: In the present study, patients will be sent a message shortly after completing a medical procedure that informs or reminds them that they can reach out to Geisinger, and how to do it, if they have any medical issues or concerns. Researchers will assess if such messages make patients more likely to contact Geisinger with post-procedure medical concerns and decrease emergency department utilization.

detailed_description.textblock:
Decreasing emergency department (ED) over-utilization is a priority for healthcare systems across the country. Patients uncertain about a medical issue routinely end up in the ED when less costly and time-consuming alternatives could have addressed their concern. If patients reach out to healthcare facilities rather than heading directly to the ED, they can often be directed toward resources better suited to their concerns than the ED.
Geisinger is thus working to encourage patients to contact healthcare providers if any concerns arise and patients are uncertain about where to go for care. Patients who have recently had a medical procedure may be particularly valuable to encourage, as they routinely have concerns related to the procedure and discharge can serve as a useful touch-point to remind the patient where they can go for questions or concerns.
In the present study, patients will be sent a patient portal message shortly after completing any Women's Health medical procedure. The message will inform or remind patients how they can reach Geisinger if they have any medical issues or concerns. The purpose of this study is to assess if such messages make patients more likely to contact Geisinger with medical concerns and, in turn, decrease unnecessary ED utilization. This study will A/B test 2 messages, encouraging patients to either call their recent provider directly or to call a tele-nurse hotline, and will assess if these messages perform better than a control group that will not be sent any such message.
Generalized linear models will examine the primary study outcomes as a function of the study arms (between-subjects).

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Throughout the study, patients will be randomized equally across all three arms.
study_design_info.masking_description: Participants (i.e., patients) will not be informed specifically of their assignment to different arms throughout the study. Providers will not be randomized to study arms or informed of patient assignment.

primary_outcome.measure: Phone calls: messaged groups vs. control group
primary_outcome.time_frame: 18 months or as long as it takes to reach N=17,300, whichever occurs first
primary_outcome.description: Proportion of patients who call the tele-nurse or their provider within 30 days of their appointment. "Messaged groups" refers to patients who received a message, irrespective of whether it was through the "call provider" or "call tele-nurse" intervention.

primary_outcome.measure: ED utilization: messaged groups vs. control group
primary_outcome.time_frame: 18 months or as long as it takes to reach N=17,300, whichever occurs first
primary_outcome.description: Proportion of patients (in the "call provider" or "call tele-nurse" arms) who visit the ED within 30 days of their appointment

secondary_outcome.measure: Phone calls: messaged groups vs. control group
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of patients who call the tele-nurse or their provider within 30 days of their appointment

secondary_outcome.measure: ED utilization: messaged groups vs. control group
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of patients who visit the ED within 30 days of their appointment

secondary_outcome.measure: ED utilization: messaged groups vs. control group, surgical appointments only
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of patients who visit the ED within 30 days of their surgical appointment. Surgical appointments are targeted as a sub-group of interest because such appointments have higher 30-day ED utilization rate and thus may have more potential for impact.

secondary_outcome.measure: ED utilization: messaged groups vs. control group, surgical appointments only
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 18 months or as long as it takes to reach N=17,300, whichever occurs first
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of patients who visit the ED within 30 days of their surgical appointment. Surgical appointments are targeted as a sub-group of interest because such appointments have higher 30-day ED utilization rate and thus may have more potential for impact.

secondary_outcome.measure: Phone calls: call your provider vs. call the tele-nurse
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 18 months or as long as it takes to reach N=17,300, whichever occurs first
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of patients who call the tele-nurse or their provider within 30 days of their appointment

secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of patients who visit the ED within 30 days of their appointment

secondary_outcome.measure: ED utilization: call your provider vs. call the tele-nurse
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of patients who visit the ED within 30 days of their appointment

secondary_outcome.measure: Phone calls: call your provider vs. control group
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of patients who call the tele-nurse or their provider within 30 days of their appointment. This will be assessed using the same regression model as Outcome #12.

secondary_outcome.measure: Phone calls: tele-nurse vs. control group
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of patients who call the tele-nurse or their provider within 30 days of their appointment. This will be assessed using the same regression model as Outcome #11.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 18 months or as long as it takes to reach N=17,300, whichever occurs first

Surgical appointments are targeted as a sub-group of interest because such appointments have higher 30-day ED utilization rate and thus may have more potential for impact. arm_group.description: This group will receive a patient portal message the morning after completing their procedure. The message will encourage patients to call their recent Women's Health provider (with appropriate phone number listed) if any questions or concerns arise about their healthcare.

This group will receive a patient portal message the morning after completing their procedure. The message will encourage patients to call Geisinger's nurse triage hotline (with appropriate phone number listed) if any questions or concerns arise about their healthcare.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patient had a procedure in Women's Health within the study period (including both surgical and in-office procedures as well as baby delivery)
- Patient is enrolled in myGeisinger, Geisinger's patient portal
Exclusion Criteria:
- If procedure was labor that resulted in fetal demise or stillborn.

patient_data.ipd_description: Data with no personally identifiable information will be made available to other researchers on the Open Science Framework for transparency.
patient_data.ipd_time_frame: The data will become available after publication of study results in a scientific journal and will be available as long as the Open Science Framework hosts the data.
patient_data.ipd_access_criteria: The data on the Open Science Framework will be open to anyone requesting that information.
